title: Ticket #3094: DMTCP doesn't work in 7.8; SIGINT ignored
description:
Report from Gene Cooperman, made by phone:

DMTCP/condor_dmtcp works in 7.2. It no longer worked in 7.8(?). Investigation suggests that SIGINT is being ignored, and SIGINT is what shim_dmtcp is using to detect a request to checkpoint and exit. This has been identified by both condor_ssh_to_job and "kill -2 PID" as well as looking in /proc/$PID/status at SigIgn. (Easy expansion of SigIgn: echo 0000000000384004 | xxd -r -p | xxd -b

Doing initial triage. - adesmet 2012-06-28
remarks:
2012-Jun-28 15:08:24 by adesmet:
Cannot reproduce. Only PIPE is blocked. Tested on Red Hat 5.8/Condor 7.8.1 and Red Hat 5.7/Condor 7.7.6. New hypothesis: init scripts on remote site are setting ignore INT?

2012-Jun-28 15:09:01 by adesmet:
Because I couldn't find a tool to easily list the ignored signals, I quick wrote one. it's attached as "describe signals".

2012-Jun-28 17:20:16 by adesmet:
Reported to work fine on Debian Squeeze/6.0 stable.

2012-Jun-29 17:23:40 by adesmet:
Current status: it looks like the job is just inheriting the ignoring of SIGINT from Condor. Why is Condor ignoring it? Not sure, but I suspect that it was set that way by the process that itself started Condor.

On the problematic machines, when Condor is started by init on boot, all is well. When stopped and restarted using the init script tool, all is well. But sometimes, none-the-less, it ends up blocked. They're looking into what's going on.

2012-Jul-02 14:36:01 by gene:
This has now been diagnosed as a Debian bug (present in Debian 6.0/squeeze). The Debian bug report is at http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=679630 The short story is that if Debian squeeze uses the dependency-based booting, then some of the early daemons in the boot process will block SIGINT. If you suspect this on your machine, test it with: 

  cat /proc/*/status | grep "\(SigIgn\|Name\)" |egrep -B1 "[0-9a-f][0-9a-f]+2$"

and look to see if many daemons (especially condor) have SigIgn ending in 2. The workaround is to kill condor and restart it again as root: 

  /etc/init.d/condor restart

For additional bugs in Condor/DMTCP integration, please also send a bug report to http://dmtcp.sourceforge.net to reach the DMTCP developers. Thank you. -- the DMTCP developers.

2012-Jul-03 17:24:27 by adesmet:
Resolved as Debian specific bug. The idea that Condor should reset signal handling as a workaround for this and potentially other bugs is #3107: Should Condor reset signal handling to defaults?
